title: chore(ci): automatically open PR to forward patch release back to main
body: After the cargo publish runs and the release tag is created, this will automatically open a PR that forwards the patch release commit back to main. In extreme scenarios, we can just ignore the PR that's opened and do it manually.

EDIT: `op_url_reparse` is 10% faster.

This add the `denoConfigTasks` experimental capability which handles a `deno/task` request from the client, which responds with an array of tasks from the current configuration file.

Clients need to implement surfacing them to the user, such as with denoland/vscode_deno#641.

title: fix(lsp): watch .jsonc files
body: We are currently not watching `.jsonc` files in the editor, which means some changes to `deno.jsonc` won't be automatically tracked.

title: fix(lib.deno_fetch.d.ts): Extend deprecated fetch() overload
body:
#14113 broke https://deno.land/x/download@v1.0.1/download.ts. The overload accepting `URL` should be all-inclusive or it won't accept an argument of type `string | URL`.

cc @kt3k

title: feat(ops): #[op(unstable)]
body:
`#[op(unstable)]` tags `OpDecl::is_unstable` as `true`, thus allowing op-middleware to then disable said ops

This should make unstable checks less error prone (forgotten or overlooked during review/impl), less verbose and moderately faster (check happens at runtime init vs each call)

title: chore: update rusqlite
body: This allows users of deno to use a more recent version.

title: fix(ext/ffi): enforce unstable check on ops
fix: deprecate URL as the first arg of fetch
body: Deno's fetch and lib.dom's fetch have slightly different declarations. (Deno's fetch accept URL as the first arg, but lib.dom's fetch doesn't) We should align Deno's declaration to lib.dom's (spec defines first arg as `typedef (Request or USVString) RequestInfo` [ref](https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#requestinfo)) to reduce the confusion. This PR tries to deprecate Deno-only signature of fetch function. With this change, fetch with URL call gets strikethrough style in vscode like the below

title: refactor(flags): rename CheckFlag to TypecheckMode
body:
Working on https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/14072 it became confusing to have `CheckFlag` and `CheckFlags`. I believe `TypecheckMode` is a better name than `CheckFlag`. 

Also renamed `Flags.check` to `Flags.typecheck_mode` and `CheckOptions.check` to `CheckOptions.typecheck_mode`.

title: feat(serde_v8): DetachedBuffer
body:
This would be useful in WebGPU, where the spec's semantics (IIRC) expect buffers to be detached.

It might also be useful in other situations where we want to transfer ownership across the op-layer rather than share ownership

CC @lucacasonato @crowlKats

title: chore: drop src/ in bench_util & serde_v8
body: To align with conventions used in our other crates

title: experiment(serde_v8): derive_more enabled opaque wrappers
body:
Experiment using [derive_more](https://docs.rs/derive_more/latest/derive_more/) to help generate magic-type wrappers with mostly opaque-ish internal types, so we can swap out Vec for SmallVec for ByteStrings. Creating them via Into/From rather than explicitly wrapping their internal type.

(Note that's just as efficient, `SmallVec`s can be created from Vec's with no copying, it simply transfers ownership of the buffer on the heap)

title: feat(core): disableable extensions & ops
body:
Streamlines a common middleware pattern and provides foundations for avoiding variably sized v8::ExternalReferences & enabling fully monomorphic op callpaths

Op middleware has the final say on whether an op is enabled/disabled/overridden, otherwise the logic is:
```
op.enabled = extension.enabled && op.enabled;
```

Entire extensions can be enabled/disabled, individual ops can also toggled in the extension constructor.

Main semi-open question is if disabled ops should throw or just no-op by mapping to `op_void_a?sync` thus returning `undefined` (no-op-ing is our current behaviour so I'm going to stick with that)

title: fix(core): variadic opSync/opAsync
body: To allow opcalls with more than 2 generic-args JS-side

title: perf(http): avoid per header alloc
body:
When checking if header matches a "special" header (that impacts our body handling, etc...)

[make_ascii_lowercase](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/string/struct.String.html#method.make_ascii_lowercase) could also make sense here

### Impact on throughput

Unfortunately there's a lot of variance in our tests and it's not fully formalized but I do observe a 1-3% improvement in throughput (sampled over 3 runs):

```
Before (1.20.1)
Requests/sec: 126285.80
Requests/sec: 127775.95
Requests/sec: 128875.33

After (this PR):
Requests/sec: 130615.10
Requests/sec: 129957.80
Requests/sec: 129056.16
```

title: cleanup(core): drop op_void_async's state arg
body: Since OpState-like args are optional since: https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/13954

title: chore(fetch, mimesniff): Refactor the "extract a MIME type" algorithm
body:
`Request.prototype[_mimesniff]` and `Response.prototype[_mimesniff]` are functions that implement the "extract a MIME type" algorithm from the fetch spec. These implementations are the same line by line, though. This change deduplicates that by moving most of the implementation to a `extractMimeType` function under `ext/web`'s `01_mimesniff.js`, and simply calling that with the decoded and split headers from the `[_mimesniff]` functions.

Closes #14002.

title: feat(test): Add "name", "origin" and "parent" to "Deno.TestContext"
body:
This PR includes features for implementing snapshot test feature (assertSnapshot) in `deno_std`.
- Exposes the current test name.
- TestContext includes their parentContext. (.parent)
- Add origin (I think we can use this instead of `import.meta.url` or `Deno.mainModule` to get the path of snapshot).  
- ~~Teardown API to call function after the test finished.~~
- ~~Add update flag on cli/test for snapshot update mode.~~

related comment is here: https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/3635#issuecomment-1069149310

I wrote simple test for this code, but I am not sure where I have to put this test file. please let me know where to put and how to run this test in the project structure. thanks!
```typescript
Deno.test('test name', (t) => {
	t.name; // This will be `test name`
	t.origin; // `file:///Users/me/deno.test.ts`

	t.step('test name2', (t2) => {
		t2.name; // This will be `test name2`
		t2.origin; // `file:///Users/me/deno.test.ts`
	})
})
```

title: chore(wasm): Don't await on the argument to `handleWasmStreaming`
body:
`handleWasmStreaming` is the function that provides the binding with the `fetch` API needed for `WebAssembly.instantiateStreaming()` and `WebAssembly.compileStreaming()`. When I implemented it in #11200, I thought V8 was calling these functions with the argument of the `WebAssembly` streaming functions, without doing any resolving, and so `handleWasmStreaming` awaits for the parameter to resolve. However, as discovered in https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/13917#issuecomment-1065805565, V8 does in fact resolve the parameter if it's a promise (and handles rejections arising from that).

This change removes the `async` IIFE inside `handleWasmStreaming`, letting initial errors be handled synchronously (which will however not throw synchronously from the `WebAssembly` namespace functions). Awaiting is still necessary for reading the bytes of the response, though, and so there is an `async` IIFE for that.

----------------------

This PR builds on #13925, not because the changes depend on those of that PR, but because this PR changes the stack trace in one of that PR's test outputs.

title: build: use workflows for bumping versions and cargo publishing on the CI
body:
See tools/cut_a_release.md for how this would work.

Essentially:

1. User kicks off "version_bump" workflow on branch that they want to do a release from.
    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1609021/160151787-3e0fcdea-7861-4de7-bb4a-380534dca2a5.png)
2. A PR gets opened automatically, see https://github.com/dsherret/deno/pull/3 for an example (Note: the actual changes in there are messed up because I did a force push to my branch, but you can see from the PR body how it will look).
3. The person doing the release updates the PR if necessary and merges it.
4. After merge they kick off the "cargo_publish" workflow, which will publish all the crates and tag the repo which will kick off the release workflow which creates the draft.

Closes #13874

title: fix: cargo publish fails without absolute paths
body:
https://github.com/denoland/deno/commit/4e3ed37037a2aa1edeac260dc3463a81d9cf9b88 was erroneous and broke `cargo publish`.  I've opened https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/13994 that would allow us to catch errors like this in the future.

1.20.1 will be released after this is landed.

title: chore: release script should automatically figure out CLI crate dependencies
body:
Fixes the issue we saw with the last release.

This is the output now:

```
Setting deno to 1.20.1...      
Set version to 1.20.1
Setting deno_core to 0.124.0...
Setting serde_v8 to 0.35.0...
Setting deno_ops to 0.2.0... 
Setting deno_bench_util to 0.36.0...
Setting deno_runtime to 0.50.0...   
Setting deno_webstorage to 0.37.0...
Setting deno_web to 0.73.0...
Setting deno_webidl to 0.42.0...
Setting deno_url to 0.42.0...
Setting deno_websocket to 0.47.0...
Setting deno_tls to 0.29.0...
Setting deno_webgpu to 0.43.0...
Setting deno_net to 0.34.0...
Setting deno_http to 0.36.0...
Setting deno_ffi to 0.29.0...
Setting deno_fetch to 0.65.0...
Setting deno_crypto to 0.56.0...
Setting deno_console to 0.42.0...
Setting deno_broadcast_channel to 0.36.0...
```

Previously (deno_ops missing):

```
Setting deno to 1.20.1...
Set version to 1.20.1
Setting deno_bench_util to 0.36.0...
Setting serde_v8 to 0.35.0...
Setting deno_core to 0.124.0...
Setting deno_broadcast_channel to 0.36.0...
Setting deno_console to 0.42.0...
Setting deno_crypto to 0.56.0...
Setting deno_web to 0.73.0...
Setting deno_url to 0.42.0...
Setting deno_webidl to 0.42.0...
Setting deno_fetch to 0.65.0...
Setting deno_tls to 0.29.0...
Setting deno_ffi to 0.29.0...
Setting deno_http to 0.36.0...
Setting deno_websocket to 0.47.0...
Setting deno_net to 0.34.0...
Setting deno_webgpu to 0.43.0...
Setting deno_webstorage to 0.37.0...
Setting deno_runtime to 0.50.0...
```

title: v1.20.0
body:
<!--
Before submitting a PR, please read http://deno.land/manual/contributing

1. Give the PR a descriptive title.

  Examples of good title:
    - fix(std/http): Fix race condition in server
    - docs(console): Update docstrings
    - feat(doc): Handle nested reexports

  Examples of bad title:
    - fix #7123
    - update docs
    - fix bugs

2. Ensure there is a related issue and it is referenced in the PR text.
3. Ensure there are tests that cover the changes.
4. Ensure `cargo test` passes.
5. Ensure `./tools/format.js` passes without changing files.
6. Ensure `./tools/lint.js` passes.
-->

title: feat(ext/net): Deno.upgradeHttp handles unix connections
body: ## merge on approval

title: chore: uploading WPT shouldn't make CI fail
body:
We had two successive main branch failures related to this.
- https://github.com/denoland/deno/runs/5566541876?check_suite_focus=true
- https://github.com/denoland/deno/runs/5566531944?check_suite_focus=true

title: perf(web): optimize Blob.text and Blob.arrayBuffer
body:
```
blob_text_large:     	n = 100, dt = 0.655s, r = 153/s, t = 6550000ns/op
```

title: perf(web): use DOMString for BlobParts
body:
70% faster than Node (24ms)
50% faster than Bun (14ms)

(above numbers taken from https://twitter.com/jarredsumner/status/1503888103227867136)

Before:
```
blob_text_large:     	n = 3, dt = 2.123s, r = 1/s, t = 707666666ns/op
```

After:
```
blob_text_large:     	n = 3, dt = 0.021s, r = 143/s, t = 7000000ns/op
```

Closes #13973

title: feat(lsp): support deno.enablePaths setting
body:
Ref: denoland/vscode_deno#633

This is functionally working, just need to write tests, but this branch plus https://github.com/denoland/vscode_deno/pull/635 should allow folks to take it for a test spin. @dsherret especially if you could give it a spin on Windows.  I think I have done everything to make it work well, but windows always has surprises.

title: chore(cli): Disallow cross compiling for snapshots
body: Better error message than a confusing runtime error (as seen in https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/13948 & https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/4862) until https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/13948 is solved

title: fix(core): nuke Deno.core.ops pre-snapshot
body: To avoid OOB & other ExternalReference snapshot serialization issues

title: feat(ext/fetch): Allow Response status 101
body:
Necessary for https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/13618
<!--
Before submitting a PR, please read http://deno.land/manual/contributing

1. Give the PR a descriptive title.

  Examples of good title:
    - fix(std/http): Fix race condition in server
    - docs(console): Update docstrings
    - feat(doc): Handle nested reexports

  Examples of bad title:
    - fix #7123
    - update docs
    - fix bugs

2. Ensure there is a related issue and it is referenced in the PR text.
3. Ensure there are tests that cover the changes.
4. Ensure `cargo test` passes.
5. Ensure `./tools/format.js` passes without changing files.
6. Ensure `./tools/lint.js` passes.
-->

title: feat(task): add unstable warning to `deno task`
body: Moving `deno task` to unstable. This will allow us to validate the approach before stabilizing it.

title: chore(test_util): use pretty_assertions when not pattern matching
body: If the assertion string doesn't contain "[WILDCARD]" then it uses `pretty_assertions::assert_eq` for better output.
